history.content:
Probably not. You can always take 290T in grad school, but 61c and 120 are needed for lots of other classes one would reasonably be expected to take in undergrad (e.g. 162 for 61c, 123 for 120). 

============================================================================================

I'd say its worth it! You could always take those courses later, as they are offered often. Especially if you are ahead in your classes (aka on track to finish all your graduation requirements with maybe a semester to spare), I think it would be really eye opening to take a class you are so interested in. 

If you could, I would try to sign up for all 4 classes, and then either drop EE290T if it doesn't live up to your expectations, or drop 61C/EE120 if it does! You have 4 and a half weeks til the drop deadline (double check if any classes are early drop deadline, though!)
Probably not. You can always take 290T in grad school, but 61c and 120 are needed for lots of other classes one would reasonably be expected to take in undergrad (e.g. 162 for 61c, 123 for 120).

children.subject: 290T looks to be more of a computer vision class than a signal processing class

I caution you against taking some of the more advanced signal processing classes without a good probability background. I took EE 123 this past spring (which should, in theory, be less advanced than 290T since it's an undergrad class) with CS 70 concurrently and there were a number of concepts that I completely missed out on understanding or made no sense at all to me because I had never seen probability before. 70 and/or any knowledge of probability wasn't even listed as a prereq for 123, whereas it is here. In my opinion, the department really should be emphasizing 70 (and even 126) as prereqs for the 123/225B/290T domain in the same way 126/127 are for 189 (although, to be fair, I suspect this has mostly to do with less people being into SP than ML).

Now, that said, I have no idea what 290T will be like and how heavily it will lean on probability. My advice would be to enroll in it and drop after 3-4 weeks if you can't handle it or don't care for it.

Does anyone know how heavy this class is? It seems like your entire grade revolves around participation and one final project. There are no exams for this class. A class like this can either be extremely difficult because the professor is strict about the project, or a relatively light survey course that serves more to inspire interest in the topic.

history.content:
Hi everyone, 

I'm currently signed up to take CS70, CS61C, EE120 this upcoming semester. However, I recently got an email regarding EE290T - 3D Reconstruction and Recognition, and am very interested in taking this class, especially considering it might not be offered again because it is a special topics course. I emailed the professor and he said that I should be OK taking EE290 even though I am taking 70 concurrently. Considering that 120, 61C, and 70 are core classes, is it worth dropping either 120 or 61C to take EE290T? For context, I am interested in ML/AI and am considering grad school in those areas. I would really appreciate some advice on this. 

Thanks!
history.subject: Course selection assistance
